questions.text: A 34-year-old presents to the casualty with a history of blunt force trauma to the head. A small lesion was found on the dorsal aspect of the brainstem on imaging. Which of the following nerves could be injured at the site?
questions.solution:
The trochlear nerve is the only nerve that exits the brainstem on the dorsal surface and thus can be injured in this patient. 

All other cranial nerves exit the brainstem from the ventral surface.

questions.text: A person who was in deep sleep with arms under his head after alcohol-intoxication now presents with Saturday night palsy. Which of the following sensations would remain relatively intact in him?
questions.solution:
Pain sensations would remain relatively intact in persons with Saturday night palsy. 

Sleeping for a long period with the arms under the head puts pressure on a nerve, leading to the loss of conduction in large-diameter motor, touch, and pressure fibers, while pain sensation remains relatively intact.

questions.text: What does the operon model attempt to explain?

choices.text: The coordinated control of gene expression in bacteria
How genes move between homologous regions of DNA
The mechanism of viral attachment to a host cell

questions.solution:
The operon model attempts to explain the coordinated control of gene expression in bacteria.

In bacteria, the structural genes that code for proteins, involved in a particular metabolic pathway are often found sequentially grouped on the chromosome along with the cis-acting regulatory elements that determine the transcription of these genes.

The transcription product is a single polycistronic messenger RNA (mRNA).

The genes are thus coordinately controlled, that is, turned on or off as a unit. This entire package is referred to as an operon.

Note: Gene regulation in bacteria is important in order to:

  • Enable response to environmental stimuli
  • Allow cells to adjust promptly to changes in the growth medium
  • Alter biochemical capabilities appropriate for available substrate

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding primary myelofibrosis.

choices.text: Common in individuals less than 30 years of age
White blood cell count is elevated in the initial phase
Advanced disease is characterised by diffuse fibrosis of bone marrow and splenomegaly
Peripheral smear shows the presence of leukoerythroblastosis and dacryocytes

questions.solution:
The false statement regarding primary myelofibrosis is that it occurs in individuals less than 30 years of age.

Myelofibrosis is characterized by abnormal production of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets, in association with marrow fibrosis (scarring) and extramedullary hematopoiesis. It can present de novo as primary myelofibrosis (PMF), a chronic progressive myeloproliferative disorder or due to an underlying disorder such as leukemia or hyperparathyroidism, in which case it is called secondary or reactive myelofibrosis.

Primary myelofibrosis occurs in individuals over 60 years of age. JAK2, CALR, and MPL mutations are seen in the majority of the cases. Patients present with vague, constitutional symptoms such as weight loss, night sweats, low-grade fever, cachexia, fatigue, and pruritus. There might be a history of exposure to industrial solvents or radiation. Later in the disease, there may be a sensation of fullness in the upper left quadrant due to splenomegaly. Hyperuricemia and secondary gout may also occur.

Peripheral smear shows the presence of normochromic normocytic anemia and leukoerythroblastosis. There is a release of nucleated erythroid and early granulocyte progenitors from the bone marrow and the presence of dacryocytes, which are tear-drop-shaped red cells. 

Early in the disease, the WBC count is markedly elevated up to 100,000 cells/mm3 but later the count usually returns to normal or is reduced, even.

The chief pathologic feature is the extensive deposition of collagen in the marrow by fibroblasts. The fibrosis of bone marrow is thought to be caused by the inappropriate release of platelet-derived growth factor and TGF-β. Early in the disease, the marrow is hypercellular with an increase in the maturation of cells of all lineages but with disease progression and collagen deposition, the bone marrow becomes hypocellular and diffusely fibrotic. Eventually, the fibrotic marrow space is converted to bone, which is called osteosclerosis.

Due to the obliteration of marrow space by fibrotic changes, there is extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis mainly in the spleen, giving rise to massive splenomegaly. Subcapsular infarcts are common and there may be moderate enlargement of the liver. There is no significant lymphadenopathy, though hematopoiesis may occur even in the lymph nodes.

The complications include recurrent infections, thrombotic episodes, platelet anomalies leading to bleeding diathesis, and sometimes, transformation into acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Janus kinase inhibitors like ruxolitinib and fedratinib have been approved for management. Hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplantation may also be considered depending on factors like the patients' age and fitness for the procedure.

questions.text: A  26-year-old male patient presents with painful ulcers on his penis with the classical "kissing ulcer" appearance. He also has tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.  If the ulcer is swabbed, which of the following will be found on microscopy?
questions.solution:
This patient with tender genital ulcers with the "kissing ulcer" appearance and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy most likely has a diagnosis of chancroid. 

If the ulcer is swabbed, the classical "school of fish"/"railroad track" appearance will be seen on microscopy, as shown below:

Chancroid is a type of sexually transmitted infection (STD) that is caused by the bacteria Haemophilus ducreyi, a Gram-negative coccobacillus. It presents with painful genital ulceration along with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy that may develop into buboes. Auto-inoculation by the organism can result in new ulcers merging with the older ones. Hence, they are called "kissing ulcers".

The diagnosis is made clinically and can be supported by the gram stain findings. Treatment is recommended with a single dose of azithromycin (1g oral) or ceftriaxone (250mg intramuscular).

Chancroid has gained clinical significance because it can increase the risk of HIV transmission. Hence, it is important to identify and treat these patients and to inform their sexual partners.

 Spirochetes are seen on dark field microscopy in syphilitic ulcers. They are caused by Treponema pallidum and present with a single, painless genital ulcer with painless inguinal lymphadenopathy. The diagnosis can be confirmed by specific treponemal tests such as fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS), Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test (TPHA) and the enzyme immunoassay (EIA)Treatment is with parental Penicillin G, irrespective of the stage of the disease. Dose and duration depend on the clinical stage and presentation. 

Darkfield microscopy with spirochetes are shown below:

Donovan bodies are seen in granuloma inguinale, which is caused by Calymmatobacterium granulomatis. It presents with painless beefy red ulcers. Inguinal lymph nodes are not usually enlarged, but the infection can spread subcutaneously and give the appearance of "pseudo buboes". The diagnosis is made by Giemsa staining which shows the Donovan bodies which show bipolar staining ("safety-pin appearance"). Management is with a course of azithromycin.

 The slide below shows Donovan bodies with the safety-pin appearance:

Multinucleated giant cells are seen on Tzanck smear in herpes genitalis. These ulcers are caused by herpes simplex type 2 virus and present as a cluster of vesicles on an erythematous base with painful inguinal lymph nodes. The diagnosis can be made with an initial Tzanck smear by deroofing the vesicles and taking a swab. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing can be used to confirm this diagnosis. The first-line drug used to treat herpes genitalis is oral aciclovir.

Tzanck smear with the above-mentioned findings can be seen below:

questions.text:
A child with impaired cognitive function was admitted for evaluation in the pediatrics ward. On examination, you find multiple types of seizures, an EEG showing slow (<3Hz) spike and wave discharges, and diagnosed with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. Which among the following options is a first-line drug for his condition?

EEG: Electroencephalogram
questions.solution:
Sodium valproate is a first-line drug for the treatment of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.

Valproate is an broad spectrum antiseziure drug. It is used in:

  • Partial seizures
  • Generalised tonic-clonic seziures (GTCS)
  • Absence seziures
  • Myoclonic seziures 
  • Atonic seziures

Valproate act via multiple mechanisms like:

  • Prolonged sodium channel inactivation
  • Attenuation of calcium-mediated 'T' current 
  • Enhanced release of  inhibitory transmitter GABA due to inhibition of its degradation and increasing its synthesis from glutamic acid
  • Inhibition of excitatory NMDA glutamate receptors

Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is a rare severe form of childhood epilepsy. It is characterized by a triad of:

  • Multiple types of seizures including GTCS, atonic, myoclonic, atypical absence seizures
  • <3Hz spike and wave pattern in EEG
  • Impaired cognitive function

They are predominantly seen in early childhood between the age group of 1 to 7 years peaking at around 3 years of age. Intellectual impairment in the form of developmental delay starts usually after the occurrence of seizures.

Other options:

Option A- Zonisamide is an antiepileptic drug used as adjuvant therapy of focal seizures in adults. It can also be used as an add-on in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. 

Option B: Levetiracetam is also effective in most of the seizures present in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, but is not a first-line drug for this condition.

Option D: Vigabatrin is also effective in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, but is not a first-line drug for this condition.

questions.text: The following postmortem staining is seen in ____?
questions.solution:
The image above is characteristic of Cherry red postmortem lividity. It is seen in carbon monoxide poisoning.

Related Pearl: Color of Postmortem Hypostasis in Various Conditions

Poisoning/Condition Postmortem staining

Carbon monoxide   

Cherry red
Cyanides     

Brick red/dark pink

Potassium chlorate

 Chocolate brown 
Phosphorous  Dark brown 
Nitrites   

Red brown

Hydrogen sulphide

Bluish green
Opium   Grayish/black
Asphyxia Dark purple
Hypothermia Bright pink
Septic abortion (Cl. Welchii infection) Brown/pale bronze

questions.text: Sinus that continues to develop till early adulthood is the _________.
questions.solution:
The frontal sinus develops until early adulthood.

The sphenoid sinus is the last sinus to develop.

The maxillary sinus is the first sinus to start developing in our body.

The ethmoid sinuses are present at birth and will attain their adult size by the early teens.

NOTE: The frontal sinus develops well past the late teens into early adulthood. The sphenoid sinus completes its development by the third decade.

The MCQ has been revised for factual accuracy.

questions.text: Identify the refractive error in the image.
questions.solution: The above image represents the rays of light forming two focal points one before the retina and one on the retina. This type of astigmatism is called simple myopic astigmatism.

questions.text: What is the range of body mass index (BMI) for class I obesity in global population?
questions.solution:
The range of BMI for class I obesity for the global population is 30.00-34.99.

People categorized as class I, class II, and class III obesity have moderate, severe, and very severe susceptibility to comorbidities respectively.

Body mass index (BMI) is a statistical index of weight-for-height that is commonly used to classify underweight, overweight, and obesity in adults. It is defined as the weight in kilograms divided by the square of the height in meters (kg/m2).

Classification Global population (kg/m2)  

Indian population

(kg/m2)
Underweight <18.5

<18.5
Normal  18.5-24.99 18.5-22.99
Overweight 25-29.99 23-24.99 (and at-risk)
Obesity >30 >25
Class I obesity 30.0-34.9  25- 29.9
Class II Obesity 35.0 to 39.9  >30
Class III Obesity (severe, extreme, massive) ≥40  

These BMI values are age-independent and the same for both sexes.

The risks that are associated with increasing BMI are continuous and graded. They begin at a BMI above 25.

BMI fails to distinguish between muscle weight and weight due to fat. The percentage of body fat mass increases in both genders till the age of 60-65 years. It is higher in women than in men of equivalent BMI.

questions.text: Where is the headquarters of the following organization located?
questions.solution:
The given image is the logo of the World Health Organization, WHO that has its headquarters located in Geneva, Switzerland.

WHO is a specialized, non-political health agency of the United Nations. It came into force on the 7th of April 1948. Its prime objective is the attainment by all people of the highest level of health. The structure of the WHO comprises the World Health Assembly, the Executive Board, and the Secretariat. 

 The responsibility of the WHO is in the following broad areas:

  1. Prevention and control of specific diseases
  2. Development of comprehensive health services
  3. Family health
  4. Environmental health
  5. Health statistics
  6. Biomedical research
  7. Health literature and information
  8. Co-operation with other international organizations

The headquarters of regional offices of WHO are:

  • The Southeast Asian regional office (SEARO) is in New Delhi, India
  • The African regional office is in Brazzaville, Republic of Congo.
  • The American regional office is in Washington D. C., USA.
  • The European regional head office is in Copenhagen, Denmark.
  • The Eastern Mediterranean regional office is in Alexandria, Egypt.
  • The Western Pacific regional office is in Manila, Philippines.

The headquarters of other important organizations are:

  • The headquarters of UNICEF and UNDP is in New York, USA.
  • The headquarters of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) is in Rome, Italy.

Note: Other organizations that have headquarters in Geneva are the International Labor Organization (ILO) and the International Red Cross Society.

questions.text: During your rural posting, you are asked to educate a small, uneducated village about the importance of routine antenatal care for pregnant mothers. You want to deliver some statistical data to emphasize its importance. Which of the following is the best way to do so?
questions.solution:
Pictogram is the best method of presenting data among people, who cannot understand orthodox charts. 

In this method, small pictures or symbols are used to present the data. Fractions of the picture are used to represent numbers smaller than the value of a whole symbol. Basically, pictograms are a form of bar charts.

Other options

Option B- Line diagrams are mainly used to show the trend of events in a given period of time. For example trend of dengue cases in Asia during 2018-21.

Option C- Histogram is a pictorial diagram of a frequency distribution that consists of a series of blocks. The frequencies are given along the vertical axis and class intervals on the horizontal axis. The area of each block obtained is proportional to frequency. 

Option D- Frequency polygon is the diagrammatical representation of frequency distribution obtained by joining the midpoints of the histogram blocks.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male patient with type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension comes for a routine examination. He is on ramipril for hypertension and metformin for diabetes. On evaluation, he is found to have hyperkalemia and acidemia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

RTA- Renal tubular acidosis
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is RTA type IV.

The above clinical features of diabetes, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ramipril), hyperkalemia and acidemia are suggestive of type IV renal tubular acidosis. 

Type IV renal tubular acidosis (hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism) occurs in type 1 or 2 diabetes mellitus. It is more commonly seen in diabetic nephropathy induced destruction of juxtaglomerular apparatus, sickle cell disease, drugs like ACEI/ARBs, potassium-sparing diuretics, calcineurin inhibitors, NSAIDs, and heparin.

The clinical features seen in Type IV RTA are:

  • Hyperkalemia: Hypoaldosteronism results in an increase in potassium concentration. 
  • Metabolic acidosis: Hyperkalemia impairs ammonia production in the proximal tubule that reduces the buffering of hydrogen ions. This results in decreased hydrogen ion excretion. 
  • Urinary pH<5.5: Due to the decreased production of ammonia in the proximal tubule, it leads to excess protons being excreted in the renal tubules thus decreasing the urinary pH.

Other options:

Option A- RTA type I (distal RTA) is seen in autoimmune diseases like Sjogren's syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, medullary sponge kidney disease, cirrhosis, drugs like amphotericin B, lithium etc., The patients develop hypokalemia, metabolic acidosis with an alkaline urine (urinary pH >5.5). 

Option B- RTA type II (proximal RTA) is seen in Fanconi syndrome, plasma cell dyscrasia, cystinosis, Wilson's disease, drugs like ifofsamide, heavy metals etc., The patients develop hypokalemia, metabolic acidosis with an acidic urine (urinary pH <5.5). There is also excretion of glucose, urate and amino acids.

Option C- RTA type III (mixed RTA) is seen in inherited mutations of carbonic anhydrase II. A combined pathology of type I and type II RTA is seen in this type. It results in hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman came with complaints of headache for the past 1-month. She also reported aching of the jaw during her meals. Over the last week, she has experienced episodes of painless visual loss which lasted for around 10 minutes. Which of the following is the best investigation for the diagnosis of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of headache, jaw claudication, and painless visual loss is suggestive of giant cell arteritis. The best investigation for the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis is temporal artery biopsy.

Histopathology shows panarteritis with the presence of mononuclear cells and giant cells. Due to the focal nature of giant cell arteritis, adequate biopsy requires at least a 1 cm segment with serial sectioning of the specimen.

questions.text: In the given acid-base nomogram diagram, areas marked A and D indicate which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Chronic respiratory acidosis , acute metabolic alkalosis
Acute Metabolic alkalosis , acute respiratory acidosis
Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis
Acute respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis

questions.solution:
In the given illustrated acid-base nomogram, the letters A and D indicate acute respiratory acidosis and acute respiratory alkalosis.

The illustration above shows the acid-base nomogram, which is plotted as arterial HCO3- against arterial blood pH. The shaded areas are the confidence limits or range of values of the normal respiratory and metabolic compensations for primary acid-base disturbances.

questions.text: FDA has recently sanctioned emergency use authorization to the first oral antiviral drug combination for the treatment of COVID-19. This drug combination contains:
questions.solution:
FDA recently sanctioned emergency use authorization to a combination of nirmatrelvir and ritonavir tablets (Paxlovid) for the treatment of mild-to-moderate COVID-19. It is the first oral antiviral for the treatment of COVID-19.

Nirmatrelvir is a peptidomimetic inhibitor of the SARS-CoV-2 main protease (Mpro). Inhibition of this enzyme makes the virus incapable of processing polyprotein precursors and thus prevents viral replication.

Ritonavir is an HIV-1 protease inhibitor. It inhibits the CYP3A-mediated metabolism of nirmatrelvir which results in increased plasma concentrations of nirmatrelvir. It is not active against SARS-CoV-2 Mpro.

Patients who tested positive with direct SARS-CoV-2 test can be administered this drug combination, provided they are:

  • 12 years of age and older
  • Weighing at least 40 kgs
  • At high risk for progression to severe COVID-19.

Contraindications include hypersensitivity reactions to the active ingredients or any other components, co-administration with drugs highly dependent on CYP3A for clearance, co-administration with potent CYP3A inducers. Adverse reactions include dysgeusia, diarrhea, hypertension, and myalgia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady was incidentally found to have gallstones during the abdominal ultrasound. She is otherwise healthy and does not complain of any symptoms. In which of the following clinical scenarios you will not advise her for prophylactic cholecystectomy?
questions.solution:
Prophylactic cholecystectomy in asymptomatic cholelithiasis is indicated only when gallstones >3 cm.

Indications for consideration of prophylactic cholecystectomy in asymptomatic patients:

  • Risk factors for carcinoma
  • Diabetic Mellitus
  • Choledochal cysts
  • Gallbladder adenomas
  • Porcelain (calcified) gallbladder
  • Solitary gallbladder polyp larger than 1 cm
  • Choledocholithiasis
  • Gallstones >3 cm
  • The patient lives in a remote location from a health care facility
  • Sickle cell disease/spherocytosis
  • Transplant or immunosuppressant therapy.

questions.text: Radical neck dissection spares which of the following structure?
questions.solution:
Radical neck dissection spares the digastric muscle. 

Radical neck dissection involves the removal of the following structures:

  • All ipsilateral cervical lymph node groups, extending from the inferior border of the mandible to the clavicle and from the lateral border of the sternohyoid muscle, hyoid bone, and contralateral anterior belly of the digastric muscle medially to the anterior border of the trapezius muscle laterally
  • All lymph nodes from Levels I through to V
  • Spinal accessory nerve
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Sternocleidomastoid muscle
  • Tail of parotid
  • Submandibular gland

 

Dissection LN removed Other structures removed/ preserved

MRND I

 I - V CNXI preserved
MRND II

I - V

 CNXI, IJV preserved
MRND III

I- V

 CNXI, IJV, SCM preserved
END I - V CNXI, IJV, SCM removed+ one/more LN groups +/- non-lymphatic structures

MRND -  Modified Radical Neck Dissection              IJV - Internal jugular vein

END - Extended Neck Dissection            SCM - Sternocleidomastoid

CNIX - Cranial nerve IX

questions.text: Identify the condition based on the X-ray image shown below
questions.solution:
The above X-ray radiograph shows characteristic ‘coffee bean appearance’ seen in sigmoid volvulus.

  • Sigmoid volvulus is a cause of large bowel obstruction and occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon.
  • Symptoms include constipation, abdominal bloating, nausea and/or vomiting. Onset may be acute or chronic.

Investigations:

  • X-ray abdomen will show a large, dilated loop of the colon, often with a few air-fluid levels. Specific signs include:
    • coffee bean sign
    • Frimann Dahl's sign - three dense lines converge towards site of obstruction
    • absent rectal gas
  • CT may reveal large gas-filled loop without haustral markings, forming a closed-loop obstruction
    • Whirl sign: twisting of the mesentery and mesenteric vessels
    • Bird's beak sign: if rectal contrast has been administered
  • Treatment & Prognosis:
    • Rectal tube insertion is successful in treating 90% of cases
    • The most serious complication is bowel ischaemia

questions.text: A patient who had undergone a retro-oesophagal goitre resection was found to have partial ptosis and loss of hemifacial sweating. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Horner's syndrome. 

The cervical sympathetic trunk is at risk of injury in invasive thyroid cancers and retro-esophageal goitres and may result in Horner's syndrome. 

Related Pearl: Horner's syndrome

Horner's Syndrome:

Horner's syndrome occurring due to occulo-sympathetic paresis is characterized by the classic triad of:

  • Mild ptosis (due to paralysis of Muller's muscle).
  • Miosis (due to paralysis of dilator pupillae).
  • Reduced ipsilateral sweating (anhydrosis).

Other features include:

  • Mild enophthalmos,
  • Loss of cilio-spinal reflex,
  • Heterochromia, i.e., the ipsilateral iris is lighter in colour,
  • Pupil is slow to dilate, and there occurs slight elevation of lower eyelid.

Cocaine test (2% to 4%): Small pupils fail to dilate in Horner's syndrome.

In congenital Horner's syndrome, the additional features seen are heterochromia iridis and unilateral straight hair.

questions.text: The most common variety of cancer cervix is ______
questions.solution:
The most common variety of cancer cervix is squamous cell carcinoma.

The two most common histologic subtypes of cervical cancer are squamous cell and adenocarcinoma. Squamous cell tumours make up 70% and arise from the ectocervix.

The clear cell type vaginal and cervical adenocarcinomas are most closely associated with DES- diethylstilbestrol exposure.

questions.text: Arias-Stella reaction is seen in
questions.solution:
Arias Stella reaction is seen with all the above conditions

  • In some cases of uterine and ectopic pregnancies, the endometrium shows intense adenomatous and hyper secretive activity within the glandular epithelium.
  • The cells are enlarged; epithelial nuclei show mitosis, hyperchromatic, polyploidy and atypical cell types. The cells are hyper secretive without glycogen content. This condition is called Arias-Stella reaction. These changes are focal and often associated with decidual reaction in the stroma.
  • Besides pregnancy, this endometrial reaction is seen in endometriosis, reaction to estrogen and to gonadotropins, as well as in gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD).

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, pregnant with twins, is diagnosed to have twin-twin transfusion syndrome. Which of the following statements is true regarding the recipient twin in this condition?

choices.text: It is called the stuck twin

questions.solution:
Congestive heart failure is seen in the recipient twin.

Twin-twin transfusion syndrome is a deep arteriovenous anastomotic complication seen in monochorionic diamniotic twins. Deoxygenated blood from the donor enters through the anastomosis into a shared cotyledon for oxygen exchange. Oxygenated blood is taken up by the recipient twin causing imbalance in the blood volumes.

Donor twin characteristics Recipient twin characteristics
Oliguria Polyuria
Oligohydramnios Polyhydramnios
Hypotension Hypertension
Anaemia Polycythemia
Activation of renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) Activation of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP)
Renal failure, growth restriction, pulmonary hypoplasia, contractures Congestive cardiac failure, premature rupture of membranes

 Diagnosis of TTTS depends on 2 USG criteria:

  • Monochorionic diamniotic gestation
  • Hydramnios (DVP>8cm) in one twin and oligohydramnios (DVP<2cm) in the other twin

Treatment modalities for TTTS:

  • Serial amnioreduction
  • Laser ablation of vascular placental anastomoses
  • Selective fetal termination

Note: Donor twin is called the stuck twin as the oligohydramnios limits fetal movement.

questions.text: At what age does a child attain half-height of the adult height?
questions.solution:
A child attains half of the adult height by 20 -24 months.

Length is recorded for children under 2 years of age with the help of an infantometer or rigid measuring table. One person holds the infant's head firmly against a fixed upright headboard. Legs are straightened, keeping feet at right angles to legs, with toes pointing upward. The free footboard is brought into firm contact with the child's heels. The length of the baby is measured from a scale, which is set in the measuring table.

Measurement of the length of a child lying on a mattress and/or using cloth tapes is inaccurate and not recommended. 

Height is recorded by asking the child to stand upright such that heels, buttocks, shoulder blades, and back of the head are brought in contact with a vertical surface such as a wall, a height measuring rod, or a stadiometer. The child should look directly forwards and the headpiece is kept firmly over the head to compress the hair.

Plotting the height and weight on a growth chart helps determine whether the child is in the normal range for their age and early identification of factors affecting growth. During infancy, growth charts can be plotted at vaccination visits, Later in childhood, it can be during visits for vaccination, minor illnesses, or during school health programs. 

The growth and development of a child between the age of 18 -24 months can be classified as,

  • Physical Development: Motor development during this period includes improvements in balance and the child develops the ability to run and climb the stairs. By 24 months, children attain half of the adult height. Head growth slows slightly, with 85% of adult head circumference achieved by the age of 2 years.
  • Cognitive Development: Object permanence is firmly established during this period and the toddlers demonstrate flexibility in problem-solving e.g., using a stick to obtain a toy that is out of reach, figuring out how to wind a mechanical toy.
  • Emotional Development: Toddlers looking in a mirror for the first time will reach for their own face rather than the mirror image if they notice something unusual on their nose. They begin to recognize when toys are broken and may hand them to their parents to fix.
  • Linguistic Development: A child's vocabulary grows from 10-15 words at 18 months to between 50 and 100 words by 2 years. After acquiring a vocabulary of about 50 words, toddlers begin to combine them to make simple sentences. At this stage, toddlers understand 2-step commands, such as “Give me the ball and then get your shoes".

questions.text: In spine fusion surgery, the screws are fixed to which part of the vertebra?
questions.solution:
In spine fusion surgeries, screws are placed in the pedicle of the vertebrae.

Pedicle screws are used in a spinal fusion to add extra support and strength to the fusion while it heals. Pedicle screws are placed above and below the vertebrae that were fused. Rods are used to connect the screws which prevent the movement and allows the bone to heal.

questions.text: All are true about transvaginal USG except ______
questions.solution:
Bladder should be empty for transvaginal USG Scan.
Bladder should be full for transabdominal scan as it creates a good echo window, whereas for transvaginal scans, empty bladder will allow visualisation of other structures.

questions.text: Cingulotomy is used for:
questions.solution:
Cingulotomy and subcaudate tractotomy (capsulotomy) are psychosurgeries that are used in the management of treatment-unresponsive OCD.

The established indications for psychosurgery are major depression and OCD.

Other indications include:

  • Chronic and incapacitating schizophrenia with severe depression not responding to all modes of treatment.
  • Chronic and incapacitating anxiety disorder not responding to all modes of treatment.

questions.text: The alternative drug for cardiac arrest if epinephrine is not effective is
questions.solution:
Epinephrine and amiodarone are the two main drugs approved by the AHA for resuscitation of a cardiac arrest patient.

  • The first dose of epinephrine,1 mg IV, is administered after the 2nd defibrillator shock is delivered and it is continued every 3-5 minutes.
  • If this is not effective, 300 mg IV bolus dose of amiodarone can be given and another dose of 150 mg given if necessary

questions.text: A newborn baby was brought to the dermatology department. His mother says blisters are formed at the site of handling as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the above condition is epidermolysis bullosa simplex.

A newborn with trauma-related bullae and vesicles at the site of handling over knees and feet points towards the diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa simplex.

Epidermolysis bullosa simplex (EBS) is a type of blistering disease. It occurs due to the mutation in the Keratin gene (KRT5 or KRT14) encoding for Keratin 5 or 14 expressed in the basal cell layer. This mutation causes the production of defective intermediate filaments. This makes epidermal basal cells fragile and subsequently causes blisters on physical pressure. The separation in EBS is within the epidermis (basal cell layer). 

The child is affected at birth and caregivers present the baby with blisters at the hands, elbows, feet, and ankle. More blisters will appear as the baby starts crawling. 

Other options:

Option B- Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by large, tense subepidermal bullae in the groin, axilla, and flexors of the forearm. Most frequently they occur in the elderly population.

Option C- Pemphigus foliaceus is characterized by flaccid bullae. The rupture as soon as they appear and crusting occurs. Most frequently they occur in adults of age 40 to 50 years.

Option D- Cicatricial pemphigoid is also known as mucous membrane pemphigoid. It is characterized by vesicles that rupture quickly and form ulcers. Mostly occurs in a mucous membrane like conjunctiva and oral mucosa. Most frequently they occur in older women.

questions.text: Which of the following isotopes is commonly used for external beam radiotherapy in the treatment of cancer patients?
questions.solution:
• Cobalt-60 isotope is used for EBRT (external beam radiotherapy).
  • Cobalt and LINAC (Linear Accelerator) machines are used for giving external beam radiotherapy.
  • In Cobalt machine, Co 60 isotope is used. They emit radiation of energy 1.25 Mev. Gamma rays produced by cobalt machine is used for radiotherapy.
  • LINAC (Linear Accelerator) machine’s cancer therapy is based on X-ray generation and not based on the isotope. The continuous spectrum of different energy radiations is produced that is orthovoltage, supervoltage and megavoltage.
